message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of intercostal retractions and unilateral diminished breath sounds with inspiratory wheezing suggest a foreign body in the airway. The right intermediate bronchus is the most common location for aspirated foreign bodies in children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has unilateral symptoms, indicating that the foreign body is likely located on that side. The right intermediate bronchus is the most common location for foreign body aspiration in children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest a foreign body aspiration, and unilateral diminished breath sounds with inspiratory wheezing suggests the foreign body is in the bronchi. Among the options, only right intermediate bronchus is mentioned as a common site for foreign body aspiration in young children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a foreign body inhalation, and the unilateral symptoms suggest that the foreign body is most likely in the right intermediate bronchus, leading to the right lower lobe.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest aspiration of a foreign body into one of the bronchi. The intercostal retractions and diminished breath sounds with inspiratory wheezing suggest partial occlusion of one of the main bronchi. The right intermediate bronchus is the most likely location for the foreign body to be lodged.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a foreign body aspiration, and intercostal retractions and unilateral diminished breath sounds with inspiratory wheezing indicate that the foreign body is likely obstructing the right intermediate bronchus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of wheezing and unilateral diminished breath sounds suggest a foreign body obstruction in the bronchus. The right intermediate bronchus is the most common site of obstruction by foreign bodies in pediatric patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of cough, shortness of breath and wheezing suggest airway obstruction caused by a foreign body. The intercostal retractions and unilateral findings suggest that the foreign body is likely lodged in the right intermediate bronchus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a foreign body aspiration, and the unilateral diminished breath sounds with inspiratory wheezing indicate it is likely located in the right intermediate bronchus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest that the foreign body aspiration most likely occurred in the right intermediate bronchus, which supplies the right middle and lower lobes, where unilateral diminished breath sounds and inspiratory wheezing were noted. None of the other options match these symptoms. Flexible bronchoscopy is the most appropriate diagnostic modality for airway foreign body, and should be performed emergently in this setting.
